Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Project: Carolina Cyber Defender Scholarship

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Carolina Cyber Defender Scholarship program is jointly offered by the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, NC A&T State University, and Johnson C. Smith University. This program prepares students to become intellectual leaders in cybersecurity. Students can pursue baccalaureate, masters as well as doctoral studies. Scholarship students engage in rigorous academic programs that emphasize both theory and practice of cybersecurity and incorporate research and experiential learning.

Each scholarship student is required to contribute to one of many cutting edge research projects led by experienced professors and develop capabilities in critical thinking, problem formulation and problem solving. The program has a rich set of extracurricular activities including frequent seminar speakers from industry and academia as well as participation in national and international hands-on cybersecurity competitions. Professional development, including effective communication as well as leadership, is emphasized. The curriculum covers a broad spectrum of cybersecurity topics including network security, configuration security, penetration testing, software assurance, data privacy, mobile and wireless security, usable security, access and identity management, computer forensics, policy and governance, security risk management, and cryptography.

The scholarship program is aimed at creating a cadre of diverse cyber security professionals to address the nation's critical need for talent in key national security as well as critical infrastructure protection positions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This SFS grant supported  forty six students pursuing academic degrees (BS, MS, and PhD) focusing on cybersecurity at UNC Charlotte. We strived to increase participation by under represented groups, twenty six percent of them are female, and thirty percent of them are African American.

UNC Charlotte provided a rich learning environment for these students.

Security courses offered during the project period:

  • Fall 2013: 14, Spring 2014: 14
  • Fall 2014: 12, Spring 2015: 14
  • Fall 2015: 15, Spring 2016: 16
  • Fall 2016: 10, Spring 2017: 14
  • Fall 2017: 13, Spring 2018: 16

Research Seminars:

  • 2013-2014: 12
  • 2014-2015: 10
  • 2015-2016: 14
  • 2016-2017: 11
  • 2017-2018: 11

We also held an annual cybersecurity symposium featuring leading industry experts discussing cybersecurity best practices.Symposium programs can be found at:

https://cybersecuritysymposium.uncc.edu/archives/archives

Students were engaged in research projects or hands on activities in the following areas:

  • Big data analytics approach for cyber intelligence
  • Moving Target Defense
  • Configuration security analytics
  • Cybersecurity competitions: CCDC, DOE, National Cyber League
  • Cyber hunting
  • SANS training and certificates

In addition students are exposed to leading edge research done by the faculty. The NSF funded industry University collaborative research center on Cybersecurity Analytics and Automation has over twelev research projects funded by industry and government agencies involving three universities (UNC Charlotte, George Mason, and Colorado State).

Six students published  refereed papers. One patent was granted to two students.
